ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Definitely improved my technique and musicality and got much better at learning repertoire quickly. Really happy with the level of teaching and all the new ideas I gained from studying with my professor.
Vocal technique, breathing, overall sounding better and having fun!
This semester we worked on bow techniques to produce fuller, deeper sounds and left hand techniques for intonation and ease of playing.
Practice singing

I worked on my technical ability, focusing on left hand clarity and the mechanics of my right hand. I worked on several movements of Bachs D Minor Partita, as well as the first movement of the Wieniawski concerto. As this was my first semester of lessons, some of the time was spent simply relearning techniques in different ways (due to having a new teacher).
I had a fun time learning new pieces and repertoire by taking this course.
I developed strategies regarding how to better use my air, voice my notes better through higher tongue position, reduce tension, and become a more musical clarinetist.

I was able to further my flute playing skills, both technically and musically. I learned new strategies for achieving better quality of sound, was prompted to make and justify musical decisions about repertoire I was learning, and was given suggestions for how to better execute musical phrases based on time period and style.
Violin performance skills!

I've been playing Double Bass for around seven years, but I haven't been taking lessons for almost four years, so I really wanted to pick back up and focus on my technique. I think I really learned a lot this semester and filled in a lot of gaps in my technique that had formed after many years without lessons. I think it also really helped me to form better practice habits especially while in college.

I learned lots this semester about my posture and tone production while playing violin. I also learned to really focus my intentions when practicing and work on smaller details to improve the overall piece.

I learned that my entire body is my instrument, and really began understanding that concept. There is so much more to singing than just the way that you position your sound, and that became a huge source of insight for me. Keeping my body in prime condition also helps my vocal performance technique.

Physiological connection to breath, vibrato, and pitch
More language - pronunciation, breath, and some basic grammar/vocab
Improve cello performance, especially focusing on breathing, playing and practicing fast passages, and playing vocally

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: you get to study for free (not really free, but you know) with amazing faculty; you get access to good practice facilities, and having credit lessons helps keep you accountable and gives motivation to set aside time for practice; not inherently stressful since its pass/fail

Weaknesses: depending on the instrument, it can be very difficult to get into a studio; not that many built-in performance opportunities (but that could be good for personal flexibility, depending on what you want); music theory co-requisite is kind of annoying; can be intense depending on the professor and your own expectations/outlook
I wish we could meet more often!
Great course to take if you want to improve your singing
The course makes a lot of sense, and it was exactly what I expected. Providing more opportunities for performance would have been nice, though.
While it was nice to have a general overview of many pieces, I think it would be helpful to concentrate on one or two pieces in greater detail during our classes.

Strengths: instructor was adaptable to my needs and wishes; quality of instruction was high. 

I can't think of any significant weaknesses.
This course is just private music lessons, so I don't think there's much to improve here. I'm very glad this is an option for undergrads at Yale.
More consistent lessons, with a stricter schedule. If one of us has to cancel, would prefer to do it more in advance.

I think the greatest challenge of this course is that it is entirely dependent on the amount of effort that the student puts in. This isn't a weakness of the course, but something that makes it, or can make it, uniquely difficult. I think the biggest strength of this course is the ability to learn one on one from an extremely skilled and knowledgeable teacher.

Strengths: I love voice lessons for credit. I am enrolled again second semester, and I really appreciate the my instructor. He is very knowledgable, talented, and so lenient with scheduling.

Weaknesses: I honestly don't have any once I received my assigned voice teacher. Any personal weaknesses from the course came from my own attempt at creating practice structure and committing to working on my own! 

The only structural weakness, for me, would be how long it took to be assigned my voice teacher. When I was trying to navigate shopping period and I did not know if I was enrolled in MUSI 345 until the final days before schedules were due, that did add some stress. I also know this time was extremely unprecedented, especially in navigating the arts and COVID-19 regulations.

strengths:
Janna is the greatest, and I feel so much more confident in my technique since I started working with her. 
Really fun exercises and warmups!
Diverse range of music

Weaknesses:
none that I can really think of -- it's never been boring!

Strengths: flexible, super kind professor

Weaknesses: if you dont have a super solid idea of what you want from your lessons it can be hard to make progress and find motivation

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For sure! If you want classical music to be a significant part of your undergraduate experience and dont mind committing the time and credits, its an amazing opportunity.
Absolutely, it's so lovely a time to get to work on your craft in a relaxed environment :)
Yes!
If you want to improve your musicianship, then take lessons at the School of Music
Only someone who is interested in pursuing solo performance or improving their solo ability on their instrument.

If you would like to keep up your musical instrument on the side while pursuing other passions, I would definitely recommend this course! You will have to take a musicianship course on the side, which is something that (as of currently) you can't test out of, so if that's something you're also okay with doing, then I'd recommend this course.

yes, if you are looking to take lessons for free of charge, I would certainly recommend this course. The required time commitment is relatively low and you can basically get as much or as little out of the course as you put into it.
Yes, I would definitely recommend it to other musicians who would like another avenue to help improve their playing.
Of course

I would absolutely recommend taking lessons to other students. The ability to take lessons for credit free of charge was something that intrigued me even during the process of applying to Yale. Having the YSM so closely intertwined with the undergraduate experience at Yale is such a unique opportunity that I think everyone should take advantage of.
Yes. I specifically took Voice Lessons for Credit, and I had insights that I never had from voice lessons in the past. If you're willing to put work in, you definitely take a lot out of the lessons.

If you're serious about breaking your voice down to its fundamentals and building it back up, do it. Janna is incredible and kind, and the atmosphere she brings to her lessons is never stiff or demanding. Even while I'm reaching for new heights in my voice, I never dislike where I'm at because she never places moral judgment on improvement.
Yes! I love music and Professor Akahoshi.
Yes. Great opportunity.
